Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: Lightweight and comfortable design; sealed ear cups isolate wearer from ambient noise; headphones fold for compact storage.
Cons: Pricey.
Bottom Line: Sennheiser's versatile headphones sound great on DVDs and all kinds of music.
Editor's note: We have changed the rating in this review to reflect recent changes in our rating scale. Click here to find out more.
Sennheiser's ruggedly constructed HD 280 Pro high-performance headphones feature comfortable leatherette ear cushions, a headband, and a foldable design for compact storage. Weighing a relatively lightweight 10 ounces, this $199 model has a 10-foot coiled cable fitted with a 1/8-inch miniplug. Sennheiser also includes a 1/4-inch adapter for use with a home stereo.
Our listening tests started i ... n our living room. The naval battle scenes sprinkled throughout the Master and Commander DVD amply demonstrated the HD 280s' power and glory. These 'phones can play loud, and their bass definition was quite good, though not the equal of Ultrasone's mighty HFI-650s. But this well-recorded DVD sounded crisp and clear on the HD 280 Pros, with the sort of detail you hear only from high-end speakers.

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: There is a lot to like and it is obvious why these things have enjoyed such high reviews for so many years. -The packaging was simple and easy to open, but protected the product nicely through shipping. -The build quality is superb. I can feel that these cans will last me quite a long time. -Most parts are easily user replaceable through sennheiser's website. -The cans are big and have no problem completely surrounding my big doofy ears and providing a nice seal from ambient sound. -The sound quality is unmatched by anything in this price range. I am learning to rediscover all of my music, and these headphones have actually caused me to respect my favorites bands more now that I can truly hear the finer points of the songs. You will hear things in songs that you have ... never heard before. -The bass is excellent and even capable of literally thumping on my head. -The frequency range of 8Hz-25KHz is really a cool experience. You will hear everything. -They are very comfortable
Cons: -They will highlight the weaknesses of your source equipment. My computers integrated sound card has never shown me any issues before, but while wearing these headphones the signal noise from the pc is very irritating and distracting. My next purchase will probably be a dedicated sound card. -They can be quiet when used with a small source as they require a lot of power. -They are closed design which works great for sound isolation, but heat can build pretty quickly. -They are pretty bulky and heavy and a bit too big to comfortably wear around the neck. -The cord is much too long for my uses, but probably not so for many others. The above is very much nitpicking and are probably not anything that i would even recommend that sennheiser address in a future revision.
These work great on an iPod, but you will likely not want to wear them for anything but stationary use. The 3.5mm plug is the perfect size and fits into the case on my iPhone without any issue. They do need to be turned most of the way up to be adequately loud for my tastes and the EQ needs to be set on bass booster, but that is personal preference. When connected to my home theater receiver they absolutely shine. I find myself listening for hours on end searching for nuances in songs i have yet to discover. YOU WILL NOT WANT TO GO BACK TO OTHER HEADPHONES. After using these I lament having to use my sport headphones for the gym because of the stark contrast in quality. Be warned... there is no going back and ignorance is bliss in this regard. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: Im REALLY glad I bought these headphones! Extremely Clear highs, studio quality deep bass. Even hits those dirty dubstep lows. They block a lot of the background noise. The can reach over 100db and makes game explosions feel real. Lightweight. The fold/tilt almost every direction. The cord is a coiled professional grade and hasnt been damaged when I get up and walk away forgetting when they are on.
Cons: -Plastic construction. -The foam/ear cushion degraded after a few months, but easy fix with superglue. - I wont get to buy another pair of headphones anytime soon, these are holding up fine.
These have the best sound per dollar. I did a TON of homework before I bought these, and even tryed a few at the store. NewEgg has the best prices you will find on thes ... e new. I play a TON of Bad Company 2 and Crysis style games. Farcry2 - these are the BEST for gaming for under $150. period. Paired with a Soundblaster X-fi, these will make any MP3 or ultra compressed youtube video sound unbelievable!! With on-board sound is excellent. Even hooked to my phone on plane rides was a hi-def surprise! Wow sound goes right to your soul! Never buying cheap headphones again! My friend had the Sony MDR7506, and they are slightly better all the way around, possibly more bass than the HD280's. The Sony studio monitors (MDR series) have metal contruction, and better quality pads and cushions, and slightly higher quality output, but over $125 more. Any headphone less priced than these is knowticably cheaper sound quality. The Panasonic 50mm speaker are toys in comparision. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: There is a reason that this model of headphones has been seen as a real gem, among both pro & casual users for so many years.
Sound quality is near-perfect, build quality is great, and unlike almost all modern electronics they are designed for long-term use (including repair).
These 'phones are comfortable (enabling hours of use at a time) & provide excellent sound isolation. The full freq. range is represented (minimal coloring), making them a great budget choice both for casual home use, & serious professional applications. If you've done mixdown work on average mid-range headphones, you will find yourself in the wonderful/horrible position of having to go back & re-mix EVERYTHING. Even casual listeners will notice things they've never heard in their f ... avorite music.
Ignore any complaints about "lack of bass" as the rantings of people weaned on "bass-boost" bullsh*t. These are not toys for children. The low end goes below the theoretical threshold, vibrating your skull nicely
Cons: If there is a flaw to be found in these headphones, it is a slight high mid-range coloring of the sound. They will work best with proper monitor speakers for A/B reference, but with a bit of practice can be used as a sole mixdown source.
There is definitely a break-in period; like wine or steak, these 'phones need a bit of time to "age" properly. I found my first pair really hit their stride after several months of use. Low end will be less developed immediately out of the box, but will mature to full richness with regular exercise.
I can't speak highly enough of these headphones. I got my first pair 7 years ago, & only replaced them with my current pair because I caught them on sale. Due to their robust design (including replaceable parts), I could have continued using pair #1 indefinitely. Even at full price, they are extremely affordable, & provide a fantastic price-to-use ratio.
Basically, I'm a lifer. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: Sound Quality, Price, Comfort
Cons: They exert very little pressure on the ears, but so little than music leaks to the surroundings
Sennheiser has a fantastic heritage of great products, however i know, like most German brands, they usually sound great on classical, jazz, light rock, aka very little bass because the music is dominated by mids and highs. To my VERY pleasant surprise, the headphones carry a very good bass response to them without mudding down the mids or crisp highs. These were 70 in-store, which is a terrific value, espec. compared to the 80 Sony's touting the ultimate bass experience, which left me questioning whether or not Sony testers understood bass, but that's a whole different topic. Bottom line, these are fantastic headphones, and are definitely ... the best in-stores, perhaps with or behind the AE2 or the Dre Series, which are double or triple the price. These are also very very comfortable because they exert very little pressure on the ear, however this is the ONLY fault in them. They exert so little pressure that a perfect seal isn't created which causes a slight musical leak to the surrounding. For $70, these are a fantastic buy, and worth the extra 20 over the trendy skull candy's. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: The sound is amazing and very well balanced. Excellent bass and mid-range response and the highs are well defined. The cord is long and coiled. The 30+ db noise reduction is there. In fact its so good you get immersed in whatever you are listening to.
Cons: None, really. I should have bought two.
At the price I got these for, they were a steal. These are very well made headphones. The noise reduction is outstanding.

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: These headphones are pretty good. They do isolate well. Soundstage is good but not huge. Hooked up to my cmoy headphone amp I got great bass and great highs. The detail is good too. They might even have a little more detail than my Grado sr-80's. These do well with all types of music...except for metal. They're great...just not for me though.
Cons: These cans lack midrange. I took off my Grado's and the first thing i thought when i put these on was "wheres the midrange?" Heavy guitar riffs sound weak. You just cant rock out to such weak guitars. The sound signature of these cans is v-shaped (ie. they have lots of bass and lots of highs, but no mids). The coiled cord can be kind of awkward too.
So anyone that says these dont have bass obviously doesnt have a headphone ... amp. on some songs it sounded like there was a subwoofer next to my head. THERE IS BASS.
Final thoughts: these are worth the $100 you can get them for. I wouldn't pay any more for them because then there are better options for about $130. Don't buy these if you like metal. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: I was using an ancient pair of AKG studio monitors, which still sound pretty good, but the Behringer headphone amp I'm using didn't really drive them very loud. I have had several Sennheiser phones in the past (my favorites: the now discontinued 414), I read the reviews and thought I'd try these. Claims that people were listening to ipods with these sounded a little exaggerated, but they are not. These things play crazy loud even on an ipod, and my Behringer amp drives them just fine-very good bass response, crystal highs. I would recommend these for just about any use. They're a little large to be walking around downtown with but personally I consider these home/studio use headphones. These have a 3.5 mm plug with a 1/4" screw-on adapter-makes them very versatile. They fold up for ... easier transport. Good build quality. The pads have enough room to fit around my ears with a little "wiggle" room to help alleviate "pad fatigue"-see below.
Cons: I have a pretty big noggin, so the band squeezes the pads against my head a little too tightly. Not really a con but these things seal well around your ears. Nice if you're playing an instrument and moving around-they won't easily slide off. But it gets a little tiring after a while.
Compared to my old AKGs these things have almost subwoofer-like bass, which I consider a good thing. Very transparent sound, though. Really worth the money. 20 years ago my old 'Phones were more than twice the price. expand » « collapse

Pros: These headphones are phenomenal. The audio quality they produce is the best I've ever heard out of any headphones and rivals my home stereo speakers. Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: Incredibly tight and accurate bass, not washed out, and at the proper volume they literally vibrate on your head (THX bass test). Snug fit, tough cable and replacable parts if need be. The high frequency response is up there too, and is not washed out by the bass.
Cons: Might be too tight fitting for some, you need flac or 320kbps to really get the high sound clarity (remember, linear sound reproduction).
Had the bose triports for quite a while... they broke. If comparing to the bose note that the HD280's feel much more durable, and the sound quality doesn't even compare - these cost less also. The sounds used to test out the frequency response was mainly Nine Inch Nails, Crysis, and THX demos.

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.ReviewTitle: Great for studio tracking and mixing
Item.Review: I have been using these HD280's in a home studio for about two weeks now. Not yet fully broken in but I am already happy. Bass extension is better than my Mackie monitors and I am getting better bass balance in final mixes using these as a check. Mids and highs seem very accurate. Feel a little tight when you first put them on but that goes away quickly and they are very comfortable in long sessions (and it has been hot here in Texas the last few weeks). Good sound isolation both for mixing and tracking - no more click track all over my acoustic guitar recordings which I was getting with Sony and BayerDynamics 'phones. Would have liked a case. No frills but very functional Look a little flimsy but feel and sound exccellent Many competitors at this price point - these are the best

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: These headphones sound amazing - the highs are crystal clear, mids are not muddy or lost, and there is quite a good amount of detail on the lows. They also isolate sound very well. I can barely hear the roaring fans of my PC and my roommates stirring around, with just the headphones on and no sound playing. With music on and low volume, I can hear almost nothing else but my music.
For extended periods of use, these headphones feel pretty comfortable, and they stay on your head securely. They also seem rather durable, which is important because I have broken many pairs of headphones by accident.
Cons: When I first tried them on my PC, I was very disappointed with the sound. It sounded very harsh, like the sound was high pitched and came out of a tin can. Then I did some ... research, and found out that since these headphones have 64 ohms of impedance, they usually require an amplified power source to be driven. Unless you have a Cmoy amp, Fiio amp, or have it hooked up to something independently powered, it will not sound that great. Don't bother using it on an MP3 player or your PC without any of the aforementioned things.
They are flat response, so all frequencies will come in relatively similarly in respect to volume. This may be good, but it doesn't add the thumping bass that some headphones do.
They also get a little warm after use, and sometimes pressure builds in your ears. These headphones also feel a bit tight. But taking them off for a little while fixes that problem.
I have been searching for a good pair of headphones that were durable and had clarity and detail. These headphones are a great deal if you can find them at the right price. The Sennheiser HD280 Pro headphones were recommended by a friend, so I found a good deal online and got one. With the right sound equipment, these things will shine! Bass impact is indeed there, but it requires an amp and some EQ'ing to bring out certain frequencies.
I am currently using them with an old RCA 250 watt receiver, as well as a cheap Creative 2.1 sound system. I hook up either the receiver or sound system to my PC, then use the Headphone Out port so that they can power my headphones. expand » « collapse

The ear parts are large, and they fit around my whole hear so that sound does not leak out. The size of the headphone is easy to adjust so i can make it fit my head comfortably. The price is also afford ... able. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review: Ease of UseThey're headphones, you plug them in, they work. The oval shape of the cups are for using them the standard way - over your head and not craddled on your shoulder like when you DJ.Quality The build feels good. They've been in and out of my bag and have not ripped, chipped, or broken. The sound is really nice and clear. Mides and highs sound great. Lows/Bass is good as long as it's in the studio or at home. I WOULD NOT RECOMMEND THESE FOR DJ USE OUTSIDE OF THE HOME OR STUDIO. Once you put the volume up really high on a mixer, the bass does not sound so great and it is hard to hear over the crowd and loud music. FeaturesThe cord is a nice length. It comes with a gold quarter inch plug so you can use them on an mp3 player and then add the plug to fit into a mixer. Once you ... put them on, you immediately notice that you can't hear anything from the outside. I do like that the cups fold in nicely and can be stored away easily.ValueOverall value is good. I've had this pair for over a year and they still sound great and have not chipped, cracked, or broken. A good buy for DJ'n at home or use in a studio. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: block out other sounds; Great audio quality; Collapsible; Inexpensive ($100); lots of padding
These are a great buy. By no means are they meant to be the best headphones out there, but they are perfect for what they were designed for.
They isolate noise very well and remain fairly comfortable. They sound great. I will note that these headphone benefit greatly from amplification. So either an amp or good source helps tremendously.
In many reviews that I have read(including on other sites), people complain about the lack of bass. If you source has enough power, there is no lack of bass in these headphones.
My only complaint is since theese headphones fit very snug, they tend to get very warm. During the summer I will have to pull them off every once an ... d awhile to let them air out. Otherwise, if my ambient temperatures are cool, the headphones stay comfortable.
Purchased mine in January of 2010, so I have had them for a year now. They still sound perfect and the plastic/rubber headband is still in perfect shape. The ear pads have compressed slightly, but that is to be expected. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.ReviewTitle: Incredible, if you know what you're looking for
Item.Review:
Pros: Where to begin... Weight-perfect; not so light that they feel weak, not so heavy that they cause neck pain. Sound-Perfect for my tastes (audiophile on a budget with a preference for slightly more bass (I'm also a gamer)); these headphones will allow you to hear EVERYTHING. If you think for a second that the frequency response is not as described, you could not be further from the truth. Size-perfect for my head; the headband is adjustable to fit a wide range of heads. Comfortability-less than perfect, but still close; depending on your head size, after hours use use, you will occasionally need to adjust them because they do squeeze your head a bit hard (only slightly). Cable-very well insulated and very long. Also, I did not buy from Newegg as these were a gift (best audio related gi ... ft ever). That is why I am not a confirmed owner. I have also put several thousand hours of listening time into these headphones, which will factor into this later.
Cons: Cable-very thick due to insulation (not inflexible) which makes it heavy. Also, its being coiled adds to the mass-per-length, making it feel as though someone is constantly tugging on the left cup very lightly.
And here's where the rant begins... For all you people put there saying you came from skullcandies and other built-for-ipod headphones, these are not bad headphones. They are designed to reproduce sound they same way they are input into the headphones. Your headphones are designed to 'tweak' the audio to the bass addicts tastes without getting expensive (if you want expensive, look up Senn's HD 800s). Trust me on that one, I've come off of years with assorted Skullcandies, including the FMJs. They are good at what they are designed to do, but are simply designed for a different listener. Second, let me tell you a little something about burn-in. IT IS ABSOLUTELY NECESSARY FOR ALL HEADPHONES! It also takes a while, so ignore any reviews about any headphones that are made with ownership as anything less than 1 month (unless the review specifically mentions burn-in). Unburned-in headphones do not sound the way they are design to. Designers factor in burn-in. You should too. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black

Sennheiser makes great headphones, and these compare to the dre beats / Bose headphones with ... great price! These bad reviews are bunk! expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: Excellent, crisp sound quality. This is the best audio I have ever heard. Able to hear the vibrations of guitar strings on certain songs. Great ambient noise reduction. They collapse in several ways for flexible storage.
Cons: Nothing major. They fit a bit snug, bit that is probably necessary to reduce ambient noise. Also, the band seems to adjust more horizontally than vertically, but it could just be my fat head. It may take a couple adjustments to get it right. No showstoppers though.
The bass is there, but a tad flat, but these are for professional and quality listening of full-spectrum music. If you are looking for booming bass, seek elsewhere - try open-back/infinite baffle sets, I think they have better bass. Otherwise, the treble is amazing, very clean ... and easy to listen to. If you like a variety of music, these are perfect. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review: Your search stops here, buy these headphones. The phones aren't completely noice cancelling, so if you are expecting this they will not deliver. I wanted a pair of phones that would block out ambient noise just enough to hear the ranges of bass and highs and lows that these phones deliver. The cord is coiled and comes with a screw-on tip for fitting into amps, etc. All in all, its the best pair of headphones for the price on the market Heavy German engineering, comfortable ear cups, extra long cord with a coil for even longer range, nice and beefy look and feel, doesnt squeeze too much on the temple/upper jaw (i wear a 7 1/2" fitted ball cap and they fit perfectly.), completely adjustable, parts can be replaced when they wear down (ear cups, cord, for example). Sennheiser is made in ... Germany so you know its built to last. No cheap plastic on this thing. You won't find a better headset for the price. They easily sound better than some of the twice the price pairs I have tried and owned in the past. I bought them to listen to music and use when drumming in the studio, and the closed ear cups make sure that the sound is directed clearly and cleanly so I can stay on tempo. Buy these phones if the price is right, you won't regret it. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black

Cons: Needs an amp to get the entire package. Mids seem a little weak compared to the bass and highs.
Overall a great set of headphones, not long after i tried them out, i was out flaunting my new hardware to my buddies. Gotta say, they sound great even without the AMP, and would recommend anyone to buy them.

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: These headphones rock!
-Very comfortable (They do feel a bit tight around the head at first but after about 2-3 hours of breaking them in they fit like a glove. -Even sound reproduction across the audio spectrum -Crisp, clean bass response (no it won't rattle your eardrums, but I don't really want to go deaf!) -I've been able to hear details I hadn't noticed on mp3's and cd's that I've had for years; shuffling pages, musicians whispering or breathing, etc. Brings a whole new dimension to the same music.
Cons: -Look incredibly bulky and dorky (but who cares with sound that good!) -Somewhat heavy -Price, but then again you get what you pay for! (and hey I got a cool sansa mp3 player with it for free, so it's cool. :)
When you get them, hook them up t ... o a computer or something that can play music for a long continuous time at pretty high volume (about the loudest you can make them and still stand having them on) and let it sit for about 12 hours - 24 hours. This loosens up the coil inside and creates a noticeable improvement in sound clarity. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review: See my "features" comments. These are some of the best sounding headphones I have ever heard. Nice and clear, plenty of volume and a well balanced sound. They blow my higher-end akg's out of the water. They isolate pretty good and are comfortable to wear for long periods. No special effects here to make them sound good. Just some really good headphones. For the price, you absolutely cannot buy a better sounding pair of headphones. Great amount of distortion-free volume available. Good isolation, clarity and detail, even in the bottom end. I love these things! This is my second pair and would never hesitate to buy another pair if and when needed. I have a set of AKG k270 studios and the hd280 blows them out of the water, especially in the bottom end and volume departments. top notch< ... br> won't find better at this price expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: Great cans for the price (when on sale)! these sound absolutely amazing. plenty of bass and fit my big head just fine.
Cons: none
people saying there is no bass must just have them connected directly to a computer or something. I have a set of Edirol monitor speakers connected via cox to my soundcard. the cans are connected to the edirols (no amp etc) and there is plenty of bass!

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: Very comfortable fit, fits around my ears and does not become uncomfortable after long use. The closed design allows for music to be heard fully without having to push the volume dangerously high. The bass response is effective, not the loudest, but is loud enough to definately feel the bass. The high end response never gets painful even at full volumes, so you won't have to throw these down when drummers go crazy on the cymbals. The cord is built well and the pad on the top of the arch won't win any beauty contest but it keeps the headphones from feeling uncomfortable. The ability to pivot the earcups is a nice feature and the foldability of the entire design is perfect. Very rugged, easy to clean, they stay secure to your head. The additional screw-on jack is a nice touch, and may ... be a must have for certain people's applications. Overall a great purchase for music lovers or audio producers who want professional sound at an entry level price.
Newegg got it to me in 9 days, in Iraq.
Cons: No case included. Utilitarian design may turn people away from this, but it is definately not built poorly by any means.
MP3's do these no justice even at supreme bitrates, MP4, OGG, FLAC all sound so much clearer in comparisson and these headphones will help you hear a lot of nuances in music that you may have been missing. expand » « collapse
Item.HelpfulCount: 1 out of 1 found this review helpful.

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review: I was looking for a good pair of monitors for mixing and headphones for listening to music on a general basis with great noise isolation. When I first opened the box I was underwhelmed, they sounded good but there was just no bass and they midrange was terrible. I ran them for about 20 hours at half volume for a "break in" period. They really opened up and sound out of this world! Every detail is audible and all frequency bands sound very natural. The construction is tough too! Pick some up. - I think most of the comments on low quality are due to them not being broken in

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review: Frequency response is great, they can handle sub and ultra sonic range when needed. They have a great fit that is fully adjustable. Frequency response is just what you would expect from such a reputable company. More SPL than you dare use! All details in construction, performance, and value are surpassed. Good value, good investment.

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: Light weight, i used to use a set of Psyko 5.1's and these are much much lighter. Great sound, even better when used with a amplifier. Bass hit's hard without distortion, i couldn't be happier.
Cons: hi mom
My computer setup is in the living room, my wife and child are obviously deaf and before i got these phones all i could hear was the TV over the music i was trying to listen to. The 32db ambient noise reduction is GREAT. I can no longer hear the disney channel in the background of everything. I can also turn these phones Waaay up, and they cannot hear them. 2 thumbs up!

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: These are great headphones. VERY comfortable both on your ears and on the top of your head. Amazing sound. These are NOT tight, and I have a large head. High quality coiled cord. Amazing highs and mids. Downright spectacular compared to my old Creative HN-700's. Pretty high quality construction, as far as I can tell. I used my Creative's so much that they broke within 8 months. We shall see whether these live up to the hype...
Cons: They're a wee bit bass-shy, especially when playing music on something that doesn't have a decent amp (mp3 players will sound a little low on bass, but these headphones still pump out good quality sound and work just fine with them). I also miss the ability to unplug the cord at the base of the headphones (I used to have two cords, one for my compu ... ter and the other for my iPod). Bottom line on the bass: These are monitoring headphones, not audiophile headphones. With an amp and without using the eq, these sound great, but otherwise the bass is fairly quiet.
There are several gripes that over people have made that aren't accurate. Headaches caused by these headphones are NOT caused by the tightness. Headaches are caused in people who aren't used to closed circumaural headphones because of the sealed pressure. Their inner ears haven't adjusted to sealed headphones, and that can cause headaches. Another issue is with sweaty ears. This is pretty much a 'duh' issue. They're closed headphones, they're black, and they completely seal the area around your ear. What do you expect? expand » « collapse
Item.HelpfulCount: 1 out of 1 found this review helpful.

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: Durable, portable, sound quality is top notch. Noise canceling due to construction.
Cons: Big. Thats about it.
After trying out cheaper models I finally chose to put forth a little bit more $$ for something that will last, sounds AMAZING and will be used every day. The Sony on the ear headphones were my first choice. Don't buy from Target as you cant try them out first. Got em home and they SUCKED! Tinny and they DIDN'T cancel noise like they said even with the battery power pack.
Best buy is great because I could try these out before I bought em. The sound quality was AMAZING. These are studio worthy and I can see using these for monitoring vocals if I was recording. I can see a dual use for the future after I learn how to use recording programs for my PC. Also ... a pleasant surprise was they canceled out noise due to the construction. No BATTERIES needed!
Anyway, these do the job, have a nice long cord and are TOUGH! The cord is thick and the ends are meant to take abuse. Although the headphones are a bit LARGE, they rotate flat so I can put them in my backpack pouch. They also fold up into a ball like shape for transport in other size pouches.
As a musician, I can truthfully say that from the music aficionado to the price conscious music student all will be very happy with this purchase. You will hear the mid-range and the highs (for Classical, Pop, Jazz or or Rock) and the BASS BOOMS (Hip Hop or Rap) It ALL sounds great through these headphones. Worth every penny. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review: perfect for studio tracking, great isolation and faithful sound reproduction across all frequencies, comfortable for fairly long periods of use. couldn't be happier with product and price. Highly recommended.

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: Full frequency response, amazing sound quality and clarity, definitely a steal at the $70 I paid and these will help me with producing/mixing/mastering music tremendously.
Provides amazing sound isolation so you can really focus on the audio streaming through them without outside interference, save a bomb going off.
Cons: The only sort of "con" I would say is just a personal preference. I have a lot of music at 24-bit/96kHz, and headphones make even studio-quality music sound "compressed" simply because there's no air. This isn't a con of these headphones, I just rather prefer speakers for true fidelity.
Don't even hesitate to pick these up if you care about quality sound with a full dynamic range, clarity and isolation. I can't see any need at all to go for anyt ... hing $200+. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: Phenomenal sound quality for the price. Great lows / Screeching highs. Comfortable for extended use. When in use the noise levels from outside are minimal at best. I crank these without fear no matter who else in the room, so long as they are on your head they won't disturb anyone.
Excellent build quality!
Cons: IMO the cord sucks. Its not braided (and really should be at that MSRP) and the coil design is a bother to deal with. Sure it extended to over 9ft, but what good is that if the coil keeps tension on your head, holding you back to the unit. Also, after about 6 ft the coils springy nature has a tendency to pull the plug right out of my PC. But if that's the only con...
No reason to remove an Egg for the cord. Its only my personal opinion. I know a few of my ... friends love the coil design. So its all just a personal problem that I had to find a way around.
I use these mainly on my PC. One thing to note is that if you plan to use these with your PC you should invest in a decent sound card with a dedicated headphone port. The front panel headphone ports can't supply the full range and power needs for these cans, causing some minor distortion. Though they still sound excellent even on front panel. Once again just my opinion.
If you have HD audio built into your PC you can use the green port on the back panel for a distortion free experience at the cost max volume.
One last side note, I pick my pair up at a competing site with a gift card, in case you were wondering why I'm not verified. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: Very clear, good noise isolation, comfortable and a great price. I've tried a LOT of different headphones and these are the absolute best I've heard for this price range. I've let my friends listen to them as well, funny enough, they went out and bought a set immediately afterwards. I use them in the office, at home and while traveling. They're fairly durable and the noise blocking in the airplanes is awesome, especially when there's a crying baby sitting behind you.
Cons: It's hard to come up with some cons but here we go: - The bass is not going to blow you away, however it is deep and clear. If you're expecting "beats" bass that literally rattles your ears and head, go buy your overpriced sub-par quality headphones. - looks/styling, they look like cheap headpho ... nes and if you saw them sitting on a park bench you wouldn't think twice about them - After wearing them for hours, your hair is pressed down where the band on the top is and around your ears.
I bought them at the sale price, but I would not hesitate to pay full price for them having actually used them. They are well worth full price. The cord is REALLY long, thankfully it's a spiral wound cord, but it makes the cord heavy and impractical for active use. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:

Cons: Size..and adjustablity. Very stiff out of the box, really need to be broken in, or they WILL give you a headache. 64 Ohm impedance, requires high volume level, to the point that some portable MP3 players wont be able to over come it.
These phones sound good for what they are. The bass is just a tad off down low the mids and highs are great. You would be hard pressed to find a better set of full over the ear headphones in this price range.

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review: I just got these in today and the sound quality is amazing. I must say that at first impression, I thought they were lacking bass. I was comparing the sound quality of the HD 280 to a pair of AKG k240s. As funny as this sounds, my glasses were the problem. I have pretty thick frames. Usually when I montor a mix or listen through headphones I keep my glasses on. With these headphones, the seal around your ears is very important; any type of leakage could alter the sound. As soon as I removed my glasses, all of the bass in the mix was revealed and a huge smile was plastered on my face. Great sound attenuation. Be warned that if you wear thick framed glasses, the sound quality and attenuation may diminish. If removing your glasses while using these headphones doesn't bother you, buy them r ... ight away! At this price you can't go wrong. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review: I work sound at church. Our worship team is generally made up of drums, keys, electric guitar, acoustic guitar, bass and 3 or 4 vocalists. We rehearse on Mondays and make a recording for the musicians to use throughout the week as they prepare for the Sunday worship service. These headphones are a major upgrade from the Sony MDR-V600 headphones that the church has. I purchased these myself after reading many reviews and I have not been disappointed! They have an excellent flat response and the isolation is incredible. We generally run between 85 and 95 dB in our sanctuary and these allow me to listen and blend the musicians without interference from the sound in the sanctuary. The quality is very good and the price can not be beat!

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review: I'm powering these headphones through my Focusrite Saffire white face FireWire audio interface and they work pretty darn well. Good all-rounders that don't color the sound too much.Pros - cheap, clear, rugged, replaceable cushioning/wire, left cup only wired, big ear padding, fold up several ways for easy storage. Even when played loud and repeatedly, very little ear fatigue.Cons - grab my head a bit tight but no pain on ears, just able to hear my pulse. Need to be given lots of juice to work properly, so probably not the greatest for iPods.I also have a pair of HD 201s and the comparison is remarkable. However, they block out a fair bit of outside sound and are easy to stow, so they've got the portability angle. I don't think I'll be lugging my 280s around town. Maybe the 201s though.Rated 4 because of the 650s and 800s... Tall about amazing... expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black

Though I would not use these for dedicated mixing, there are better open back headphones for that. And also note that there IS a breakin period, I left these playing heavy metal at moderately high volume levels and went to work, came back 9 hours later and they sounded better! much smoother so don't be turned away by the sound right off the bat. Get these and you won't regret it!

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.ReviewTitle: Great isolation and sound, but problems with the plastic
Item.Review:
Pros: block out other sounds; Great audio quality; Collapsible; Inexpensive ($100); Flat frequency response
Cons: big; Slightly uncomfortable; Plactic cracks
Sennheiser's HD 280 headphones are a closed, circumaural model notable for their substantial isolation from external noise and relatively balanced frequency response for their price range. The isolation comes at the cost of a potentially uncomfortable pressure from the ear cups, though I became accustomed to the pressure fairly quickly. With a relatively flat frequency response, the HD 280's lack the booming bass common in many cheap headphones. Advertised for professional use, these headphones are great for anyone looking for an accurate presentation of their source music, without spending a fortume.
After about ... a year of heavy use, cracks appeared in the plastic on each side of the headband. Within a couple more years, the cracks expanded until most of the plastic broke completely off. The headphones remained usable with some modification, but lost significant comfort and isolation. Based on other reviews and comment on the HD 280's, it seems the cracking plastic is (or at least was) a fairly common problem, though I have not heard of other cases where the headphones broke as a result.
With a regular price of around $100 and sale prices in the neighborhood of $70, the HD 280's are great headphones for the price, even with the small chance they'll eventually break with use. I used these headphones for hours a day for years, and enjoyed every minute. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.ReviewTitle: fantastic headphones at a great price
Item.Review:
Pros: block out other sounds; Collapsible; Great audio quality; Inexpensive ($100); fit big heads; lots of padding
Cons: Slightly uncomfortable
These over-ear headphones are terrific. They almost completely mute out background noise--you can't hear yourself talk let alone someone next to you. That is a good thing when someone is forcing you to listen to the awful radio in the car. Some people have complained about these headphones squeezing your head to tight, but for me that isn't a problem and I have a size 7.5 head. I find the comfort, especially the top band, to be perfect. The sound quality is outstanding, especially the bass. I had never used anything but cheap earbuds and was astonished by the difference. These were recommended to me by my brother who is a bit o ... f a sound snob so I know the quality is great. The best part about these is the price. I found these for $70 and they could probably be had for cheaper. I suppose there are drawbacks, including the size. But the nice thing is these fold into a nice compact block so they can't be thrashed around in storage as easily. I highly recommend these. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: Excellent, excellent sound Some replaceable parts Loud playback -- I have trouble finding headphones that I don't have to run at full volume at all times. These force me to back off a notch or two with some material.

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black

The size of the padding is perfect, they sit on my head, not my ears.

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:

The headphones themselves are quite comfortable and sturdy. I also like the collapsible design and the coiled cord because they make this great for traveling. They are closed designed so the person next to you won't hear your music. Great quality for the price.
Cons: If you listen to bass-heavy music, you will probably need some equalization. When wearing these headphones for a few hours, they can get uncomfortable due to the clamping pressure of the sets. I would recommend these anyone who wants great sound quality for a decent price. So far I have used mine for editing and mixing my own music, listening to music on my computer, and listening to my mp3 player. They have performed exceptionally well so far. Sennheiser quality! expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
I recently purchased an electronic drum kit. It was my first foray into the electronic instrument world. I needed a decent pair of headphones that wouldn't cost me an arm and a leg after spending a sizable amount of cash on my e-kit. I cruised multiple drummers' forums and I found this headset reccomended again and again. After purchase, it's easy to see why. I'm not sure you'll find a better headset out there without dropping at least three times as much. I was already familiar with the Sennheiser brand; almost a year ago I bought my fiance a high end set of Sennheiser bluetooth headphones which she adores; says they're the best headphones she's ever owned, bluetooth or otherwise.
That just carries over to these. They really are excellent for e-drumming or at your PC or stereo; the ... y do very well pulling out out each channel individually. Honestly not sure what "features" you need to rate on headphones beside their sound quality. And for the modest price these headphones sell for in comparison to some of the DJ or higher end headphones out there, they're right up there. They're solid, don't move around on my head while drumming vigorously or getting too into the music to which I'm listening. For the cost I'm pretty sure these can't be beat. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: Nice appearance, nice fit over the ears if your ears are small.
Cons: The headband was not well padded and too straight for a good fit for most heads. The bass was very poor*. To obtain a proper fit for my ears, I had to position the headband so far back that the weight would make it fall off the back of my head.
Sennheiser has a great reputation and I love my older pair (450), which needs new pads, cushions and cord.
*Another reviewer mentioned the bass issue and Sennheiser said that it was an issue that could be corrected. I contacted them but their cust. serv. response was too slow and missing their call, I called back yet Sennheiser hasn't yet contacted me.
I am assuming the poor bass was a fluke and I got a pair with the same bass problem as the other ... customer. I don't think the poor bass response was a realistic representation of these phones, especially with the many reviews praising the good bass response.
I was disappointed in the headband, which put too much pressure on the center of the top of my head and the earcup shape that required me to position the headband to the back of my head yet wouldn't stay in place.
The combined issues were too much for me to tolerate even though at $59, the sale price was exceptional if the bass issue was correctable. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review: These headphones sound amazing, especially in the mid and high frequency range. I don't know of any headphone under $100 that provides better reference sound. Lots or professionals use this headphone to mix recordings and DJ for events. For consumer use, they really bring out detail that goes unnoticed and unheard on regular (translation: affordable) speakers or headphones. It's delightful, for example, to hear all the little intricacies of Johnny Greenwood's guitarwork and distortion on Radiohead's Amnesiac. The bass isn't overpowering, so if you're looking for a pair of headphones that really accentuate the bass, you should keep looking. I read in another review that you can feel the bass before you hear it. I didn't know what that meant exactly until I tried these out. You can h ... ear all the bass in the source, but it won't overpower and drown out the mids or highs. Other reviews mentioned problems with the construction being flimsy. The construction seems very sturdy in my regular use. Other reviews mentioned that straight out of the box, these headphones don't sound great, that you need to burn them in. I burned them in by playing my iTunes library for about 36 hours on medium volume and they sounded awesome. The cord is coiled in the middle and can stretch about 10 feet. You'll want to make sure that nothing rubs against the outside of the earcups or against the cord, if it's pulled taut to the headphones, because it causes loud distracting noise in the earcups. Overall, a great performing headphone for the money, highly recommended if none of the above bothers you. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: Good Price
Cons: Too Heavy
Great sounding headphones. Extremely clear. Feel heavy after just a short period. Other than than the weight, these headphones are worth the cost.

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.ReviewTitle: Good headphones for monitoring and mixing
Item.Review: After getting it out of the box and listening to it I was pretty disappointed. The highs and mids were extremely present and the low end was next to nothing. But after running an Ipod through them for about a day, morning to the evening. The low end sounds much more pronounced. I didn't believe the comments about breaking them in but it really does work and makes them sound better. It still doesn't have the most kicking bass in the world. If your looking for mixing with them or monitoring they are wonderful due to it's flat frequency response. Worth the money I think.

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: Great sound, deep bass and crisp highs. Quality construction with nice padded ear cups and headband.
Cons: None.
An inline volume control would have been nice, but it's no deal breaker. A much better sounding and constructed headphone set than the steelseries which I bought previously purchased and deeply regret.

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: Amazing Headset. Just ridiculous bass. Sounds great for movies and music. Buy em.
Cons: High Clamp force. You know your wearing these things. They sound so delicious its worth it.
Best headset I ever owned. Gonna buy another one when they go back on sale for 72 bucks.

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: Great price, with this price, you can not find anything better than this far as i know. I have a lot of Sennheiser, from PCs, PXs, MXs, to HDs. I have a HD 598. Of course this headset is not close to HD 598, again, for the price, it definitely worth it.
Highs and mids are accurate and as expected lows really dive deep, but not too strong. A little bit muffled, still not sure if that's because I don't listen a lot and it still need to be burned.
Cons: As mentioned, muffled, compared to something tripple the price(HD 598)
For less than $80, it worth it!!

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: Clear sound and very comfortable. Cord is long enough plus it stretches so that is a plus. . You cant beat the price.
Cons: Plastic pieces that connect earmuffs to the arch are kinda thin and cheap looking.

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review: The headphone itself is well constructed and projects quality as well as sturdiness. Since it is a closed-in headset, it is a nice way to block out the outside world and be in your own world when enjoying your music. As far as sound is concerned, I'm a little disappointed because of the lack of bass and clarity of the highs. Notes that falls in the midrange are ok but other than that there are better headphones out there that is a tad more cheaper or expensive than this one.
Item.HelpfulCount: 0 out of 1 found this review helpful.

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: Very clear detail in the highs. Very comfortable, fold up nicely, long coiled cord. These Headphones cancel noise like crazy. Can really pick out various instruments and such.
Cons: Little to no bass*. What bass they do put out is clear though. I should have known this was going to be the case going into buying these. Shouldn't have gotten closed ear headphones in the first place but nevertheless the bass is almost none existent.
*Disclaimer: I am a bass addict, I often listen to music solely for phat bass lines, thumping bass and massive wobbles.
The contrast between these and my z-2300 speakers is night and day. The z-2300 has overpowering bass and the 280's little to none... sigh

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.ReviewTitle: Excellent quality, not quite as comfortable
Item.Review:
Pros: The sound quality of these is excellent, basically what I've expected from Sennheiser for the past 30 years. The construction of these is equally excellent. The ability of the earcups to fold or rotate as needed makes them easy to store and transport. They are very solidly made and durable.
Cons: The weight might be an issue for some though for circumaural, the weight is not unusually high, in my opinion. The biggest issue personally is that the headband clamps pretty tightly to your head. The padding on the earcups is adequate but the pressure is not adjustable in any way and after an hour or so it can become uncomfortable.
If you're after mobility or really long listening sessions, you might want to go after something lighter and less substantial but for sound quality ... , these are excellent. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.ReviewTitle: Best headphones I've had in 15 years.
Item.Review:
Pros: -- Incredible value during Black November sale. This could have been a Christmas gift for everyone I know. -- Rich, clear sound covering the full spectrum from brain-thumping lows to sparkling highs. These are the best-sounding headphones I've ever owned. -- Full-ear enclosures completely snuff out any sound from the outside world. My fiancee hates me when I'm wearing these. -- Tightly wound cord doesn't flop all over your desk. -- Extremely lightweight. I've worn these for hours with no fatigue.
Cons: -- Extremely tight-fitting out of the box. They feel secure, which is a good thing, but it's noticeable pressure on your cranium.
I've been using a Sennheiser on-ear headset (w/ mic) for the last six or seven years. Jumping to the these is like the difference ... between listening to cassettes vs. CDs. Unbelievable sound. Wish I could wear them all day. :P expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: Excellent bass reproduction, excellent treble clarity. Handles volume very well (very little distortion). Amazing with games, music, movies, and television. Long, sturdy cord and they fit like a dream (after a few days of a break-in period). I can wear them for HOURS and never have aching ears afterward.
Cons: None.
I have been through MANY headphones of all styles. This is by far the best set of headphones I have ever owned. I have had them for 3 years now, and they are still as comfy and amazing as the first time I listened to music with them and went "wow these are amazing". Buy a pair. Now.
Item.HelpfulCount: 0 out of 1 found this review helpful.

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: These are "natural" headphones. That is, they produce sound as it was recorded. Most cheaper headphones (and some professional ones) have bass-boosting elements or otherwise which modify sound within the actual unit. These Sennheisers, however, do not do this. Some may view this as a con (metal heads, etc) but I see this as a plus; you hear what your favorite bands (or their studio mixers) wanted you to hear.
Very durable design and construction (made in Ireland, not China!) Cord is very sturdy, well attached, and is even replaceable with some deconstruction. Comfortable to wear after several hours. Able to play a wide range of sounds/types of music equally well. (Advantage of "natural" headphones).
Cons: A little on the large side, but I wouldn't dare tak ... e them out of my apartment in fear of damaging them, so this is not an issue anyways.
Since these are closed cup headphones, they cannot be as good as open ear ones. This isn't really a con since you are trading in quality for privacy (especially good for when you have roommates), but Sennheiser does make open ear headphones with better sound quality.
These headphones are for audiophiles only! If you don't care about high-end sound quality and listening to music the way it was meant to, do not buy these headphones! Go for the Bose instead; they are similarly priced and have Bose's bass boosting technology that some love and others hate. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review: These sound crystal clear and capture plenty of highs and lows. Be careful because they are not only very loud, they completely encapsulate your outer ear creating almost a vacuum seal. That, coupled with their power can easily damage your eardrums.

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: -Fidelity. Everything is perfect clear. If you want to pick a certain instrument out of the background, these headphones are great. Just listening to songs you knew inside and out is a different experience. Also makes listening to choral pieces (as well as duets) incredibly satisfying. I've also had very good experiences with IDM and technical classical pieces. -Warm low and mid ranges. Feels almost earthy, in a good way. -Sound insulation. You won't hear anything around you at all if you have music blasting. They leak a little bit of sound, but not much. -Comfort. You can wear them for hours at a time. They clamp lightly and won't leave your ears sore.
Cons: -Take a while to break in. Out of the box they sound good, but the highs are a bit weak. -Large. They fold ... flat, but it's still a con. Also makes you look a wee bit silly. -Everything that comes with all circumaural headphones. Other products in the price range would probably have a larger soundstage, for instance. -You realize how much your music collection sucks. These headphones will make you dig around for FLAC versions of all your favorite songs.
Very good all around product that you can't really go wrong with. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.ReviewTitle: More than most can hope for
Item.Review:
Pros: I've had many headphones placed over my ears, and these by far are the best for the price. They give a nice flat response so they are great for movies and music. You hear what a movie director wants you to hear. Or you can hear what a music producer wants you to hear, with dead on accuracy. These headphones don't add any extra flavor where it doesn't belong. You hear what was meant to be heard without extra bass or other jargon.
I use them for video games as well, and they have a dynamic sound way over what you might expect. But this also brings up a very important point with these headphones. If you don't have a nice receiver, or sound card, or any other music device, then you wont get why you paid so much for these headphones. If you have some good hardware then you will k ... now right away where your money went and why you paid what you did.
Another thing to note here is that I'm a big guy with a large head and these headphones still manage not to touch my ears. This is a huge p
Cons: They need decent hardware to drive them. If you are just plugging them into an iPod then you are wasting your money and time. Find a device that at least has a Burr Brown DAC and these headphones will amaze you.
I've heard some people say these headphones lack the bass they want. The main reason isn't because they cant handle it... it's more along the lines that they are a flat response monitor headphone setup. You are hearing what you where meant to hear and not a penny more or less. If this still bothers you and you want more out of them they are more than capable. You just need to have a good enough EQ to boost what you want to hear, so you can flavor the headphones to what you prefer. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review: ... So Good.I've owned Sennheiser before and love their stuff. But, after years of owning my last pair, it was time to purchase a new pair of headphones. That being said, I was really hesitant about ordering this model [HD280 Pro] . But, after a lot of shopping around, my only resolve was to just bite the bullet and buy the HD280 Pro. Why? Well, Price-wise, this is the best for the money. I generally don't like the Sony's [in this price range] because they have tendency to add bass to what I'm hearing. If I want more bass, I'll ask for it. Yet, the Beyer-Dynamics were still out of range for what I needed in budgetary concerns, and they didn't have a model that compares to the HD280 Pro without adding some heft to the price tag. [Not that this a bad thing. I believe in paying for q ... uality, if it is in fact what you're getting for the money you spend. I would never be cheap when it comes to certain things, unless the cheaper item is actually very good for the money. This purchase was based on quality, dollar amount and prior satisfaction of using Sennheiser products.]I looked at other models, of course. But, most of those were not offering some of things I wanted, one way or another. The only way I could possible get what I wanted in a Headphone was to go up in price and that simply wasn't feasible at this time of this purchase.These are really comfortable. When you put them on, you'll barely hear anything, but when you start playing music, recording, etc. You won't hear a thing. [You may want to keep an eye on your phone light, cause you'll miss calls.]It took a short while to burn them, and it has been pleasing to my ears. I can hear some really good detail. With Flat EQ, the recording sounds like it should [to me, purely subjective]. The construction appears to be fine. I haven't owned them long enough to witness this "cracking plastic". About the only thing I wish they didn't do was the coiled cable [I like the concept of them, I just don't like having to deal with them.]. Then, with the fact that they cord is permanently attached to the left ear piece. I like it when you can unplug them to replace the cable. I once had to use Sennheiser Tech support. It was fine. I called in, I told them what was up, and they sent me a replacement part right away, under warranty of course.I say, don't expect much for your bucks and you'll be grateful you bought these for that price. If you have the budget to go high-end, then do it. But, I think if you do a little investigation of your own, you'll find that these are sweet spot Headphones in terms of dollar and quality. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: These are really great sealed monitor headphones. Meaning, they have very good (for low/mid cost headphones) sound reproduction. They are intended to accurately and clearly reproduce the entire audio range, and so they will have much less bass than headphones intended for casual music listening. You can easily use an eq to adjust as desired, however. These headphones are really best at accurately reproducing sound in a noisy environment - you can clearly hear all frequency ranges, from low to mid to high, even at a loud room, crowd, etc. These also have rotating and folding earcups, making them fairly portable/compact. The cord is user-replaceable (although you need a special cord and must remove the earcup for cord replacement). The headband padding and earpads are replacea ... ble.
Cons: They have a rather strong grip on your head, which isn't terribly uncomfortable, but is tight. Other reviewers have said this loosens up over time. People wanting "normal" headphones to just listen to music will probably be disappointed with this, especially if using a player without any EQ - the frequency response will be much "flatter" than other headphones (however, the sound will be much clearer at all ranges).
If you need very accurate full-range audio reproduction, especially in a noisy environment, these are for you. In non-noisy environments, open headphones are probably a better bet (but those leak audio to people around you, and let environment noise in). Finally if you are just looking for good headphones to listen to music with and do not want accurate full-range audio reproduction, you should not get these. Get some bass-heavy closed headphones that are intended for music listening. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review: I'll start off by saying that I don't have a lot of experience mixing audio but I'm fairly discerning and discriminating when it comes to audio. I am NOT, however, a user of 'high end' head phones so I can't accurately compare these to $400+ cans.That said, I got these on sale and I couldn't be happier.design:Big. Over the ear isolation. They are a bit tight for my big mellon but I suspect they'll stretch out eventually. The do, however, do a great job of noise isolation. Typical noise levels are completely obliterated even when the head phones are off. Robust conversation in the same room is just a whisper. Today I noticed I could hear the TV with the volume off, but it's easily [perceivably] half as loud as normal. The rule of thumb is a doubling of percieved volume requires a 10 ... x increase in power [wattage] so assume a 50W output sounds like 5W from my experience. I haven't used them in a high volume environment though. I suspect you'll clearly hear PA noise but it should be significantly attenuated.Sound:Amazing. This is by far the best pair of headphones I've ever heard. I've been running through tracks to gauge the sound. Bass is tight. I don't perceive a lack of mid though they did come alive with a bit of EQ tweaking. The highs are bright but not too harsh.I have heard innumerable new nuances since I've had the cans. Dark Side of the Moon, Track One.. I can hear what is either Port Hiss or a rattle in the studio while they are recording the 'heart beat'. I was listening to another track tonight and I could hear the timbre and resonance of a drum hit which proceeded a pause.. I'd never heard that before on any audio system. That drum resonance was so long and clear I thought it was a Bass Guitar note held until I listened closely.I have noticed a "sizzle", but I haven't isolated that yet. It may be the S/N of my hardware or the recordings I've been using. It does seem present in everything I've tried so far though. It's audible at higher volume when the audio tracks are silent. It blends out though, even at low levels.Bottom Line:I'm not sure about regular price, but if you catch them on sale grab them. I think they're great all around mid-range Cans. The Noise Isolation is Good. The sound is Good. They are well designed (they fold like origami). I totally glad I grabbed them up because I'll be flying to Spain in a few months and they'll be perfect for an obnoxiously long plane ride. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review: You ever plug a set of headphones into the mixer while you're playing, dial in your sound and then later go back and listen to the track and think, it didn't sound like that before. That's because you're using DJ or Hi-Fi style headphones. They pump up the bass and scoop out the mids and boost the highs. These WON'T do that.I'll be the first to tell you, don't mix with headphones but for detail listening, working at the synth rack or plugged into your guitar rig late at night, these things are pretty darn flat sounding.I've got a rather large cranium and I find that they're a little on the tight side but they fit around the ear nicely and isolate very nicely. I guess if they didn't fit snug, they couldn't isolate quite as well. They're rugged. Even the cable is the thicker stuff...not like ... the iPOD style cable.The padding is nice, they collapse and fold up and seem very durable. A 2 year warranty but I haven't had to test that yet. I've had them for a week now.Very pleased for the price. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.ReviewTitle: Great headphones, great price, great deal
Item.Review:
Pros: I originally got these headphones because I needed a pair of stereo headphones to experience the full benefits of binaural rhythms. These were the best quality pair I could find for the price, and I don't regret my decision at all. Full five eggs.
I've had the headphones for over half a year now, I think. They are very rugged, haven't shown a sign of wear yet, and the parts are easily bought and replaced for do-it-yourself repairs. Two year limited warranty seals the deal nicely, double that than what I've seen for comparable headphones.
Cons: The size, but that is to be expected to be honest, I hardly count it.
Get these headphones if you're serious about audio quality but don't want to put a dent in your wallet.

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: Great highs and lows, deep bass, awesome sound quality all around.
Very well constructed, sturdy.
Adjust and fold nicely.
Comes with a 3.5mm to 1/4" adapter.
Cons: Clamp tight to head... you may get a headache after wearing these for some hours.
The heavy insulation means your ears will get hot.
Bass isn't too heavy... there's better headphones our there for nu-metal and hip hop.
Originally I had bought these headphones from Sam Ash for my electronic drumset, but they have since become my go-to headphones for everything from casual music listening to gaming. I would recommend these headphones to anyone at Newegg's price.
One thing I've discovered is that these headphones are great for competitive FPS play, since the lows come ou ... t so clear. I'm going to have to get a laptop microphone to replace my $30 headset - who would want to go back to inferior audio with a pair of headphones like these? expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: I love the curled cord, great folding mechanism, sound is pretty good(see comments below. A person can use the head phones as desktop speakers.
Cons: 6 months later my right speaker shutters at some frequencies, so i'm sending them back.
I've used about 4 headphones in 10 year period, everything from 5.1 headphones on down, and by far these are the best ones yet. But on the flip side i'm not completely happy with them. i wish the sound was more full. the highs are great and the base is decent. but its really missing the mids. The search continues for the best headphones. but these arn't bad for their price. and the pros stated above really are great features.

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.ReviewTitle: Great headphones for audiophiles and casual listeners alike
Item.Review: I'm no audiophile, but I read the opinions of audiophiles all over the internet carefully when searching for a good set of headphones for everyday use. The Sennheiser HD-280 Pro were the consensus best pick in the price range, and since I got them for much less a couple of years ago, I've enjoyed my purchase immensely. I don't use headphones often, but when I do, I'm always surprised by how crisp and clear the sound is on these cans. All ranges are balanced, and the around-the-ear design of the earphones really helps to block out outside sound. Overall these headphones are perfect for my style of use; I've debated getting another pair, but it doesn't look like these Sennheisers will be dying anytime soon, so I think I'll be good until then.

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: Solid construction, comfortable, passive noise canceling (good seal), decent lows with detailed highs.
Cons: Price. EXCEPT...
...for some reason the price was jacked up here. I bought these same headphones two years ago and spent $80. From newegg. It's even documented in my order history. No lie.
Anyway, after hearing them and breaking them in, I'd still recommend these headphones at this price. They're great and are really durable with regards to physical construction and audio driver build. I've used these in all applications from normal listening to all night DJing, they always deliver.

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
Pros: Pristine sound quality. Durable design. Did I mention they sound awesome?
Very nice headphones
Cons: Lacking in Bass/lows. I listen to a lot of indie/alternative rock music and for me it didn't deliver very well in terms of the lows.
After wearing a while (4-5 hours) they give me a headache because of the pressure on my head.
Bought for 99.99 right before Christmas of last year. I'm very happy I got them for 1/2 the price they are now.
I originally purchased these for my father but he also agrees they don't have enough bass. I'll be picking up a set of grado's (as mentioned in other reviews) for him and I'll take these.

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.Review:
I almost always prefer in-ear headphones, but when I need to listen something in a noisy environment, I found Senheiser HD280 is the right thing for me. It's big and a little heavy, but I think it's still comfortable to wear since it's quite soft. Anyway, it's much better than using a pair of in-ear headphones and try to cover your ears with your hands.It's kind of big for travelling, but I think the pleasure it brings to enjoy music in crowded restaurants is worth the bother.
I don't have trained ears, so the main reason that I love Senheiser HD280 is its excellent job in isolating outside sounds. It's also comfortable to listen, with smooth and clear sound quality. I don't know how to rate its sound quality in a more professional way, but I would say for casual listeners like me, ... it should be all satisfying in terms of sound quality. It's price is nice, too. I also admitted that I love it partly because it's Senheiser, a brand of which I've heard mostly positive comments. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sennheiser HD 280 Pro - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural - Black
Item.ReviewTitle: Once you go Sennheiser, you never go back...
